name: places/ChIJ06BroA5ZwokRmnVLTxmV9rA
adrFormatAddress: 462 1st Ave., New York, NY 10016, USA

originalText.text: Being sick is not for the weak! I had a liver failure and walked in very ill. Yes, you have to wait at the ER and the toilets are the most disgusting thing you can imagine(but it’s because of the people not the medical care) we have to share it with men and women of all kinds (low higiene, etc) BUT this Doctors saved my Life! Well trained and compassionate. You just need to load yourself with patience because Doctors & nurses, they have lots of patients, they try their best! Best social workers you can imagine!!!!!

originalText.text: Listen this place is extremely busy. I really cannot complain. I've always been treated with respect by very kind nurses. Sure sometimes somebody is having a bad day but big deal. I also see my Dr at Bellevue and she's just about the nicest most beautiful lady I've ever met so there is that too.

text.text: Listen this place is extremely busy. I really cannot complain. I've always been treated with respect by very kind nurses. Sure sometimes somebody is having a bad day but big deal. I also see my Dr at Bellevue and she's just about the nicest most beautiful lady I've ever met so there is that too.

originalText.text:
I’m not a person to complain but this, this was the most degrading feeling I’ve ever had in my entire existence. I went in for a knee injury and since this the “most advanced technological public hospital that is also known as one of the most biggest hospitals” I said ehhh I’ll give them a shot. I was greeted by a security officer that was really helpful and did get me a wheel chair. Once my wheel chair arrived that’s when everything went downhill…. She yelled at the security officer since once I was picked up an older lady appeared that also needed a wheelchair. The security officer did in deed call for a secondary wheelchair but the front desk at the ER understood that it was just a repeat for mine. After yelling at the guy she then decided not to make sure I was securely seated and ignored all the times I spoke to her when I told her that I needed to prop up my leg. I ended up toughening it out and used my cane as a prop and ended up loosing the end cap of my cane and I did tell her about it but she was so focused in her robotic numbed way of treating patient that I bet she didn’t even hear me.

After being wheeled for what it felt like 1/4mile I was greeted by another nurse with “let me get your ID”. No hi or hello just straight to business. I was amazed how our health professionals treat others at this point.

I was then placed in the middle of the room since all normal areas were occupied and I did understand that. I waited about an hour of just laying there in pain and that’s when a flock of doctors came coming up to me 1 by 1 asking me the same question over and over again like I didn’t have a chart or if there was no communication within one another. There was one doctor that did come up to me that was helpful and did examine my knee and told me that the ER was only for x-rays and they could not do a MRI. I refused the x-ray since I knew for a fact that my injury was not at the bone. After the refusal I was then hounded down by several more doctors to pretty much obligate me to do the x-ray. 2 hours into this that’s when it really hit me….i was just another patient in the ER room and I didn’t matter. I ended up putting my clothes on and just walking out with my cane missing the rubber piece.

10/10 will never go back.

originalText.text: Security is directing things. I was sent to the emergency room because they refused me entrance to the dental clinic. When I was sent back despite having been given a referral for the dental clinic I was told I had to go get on the information line which was 20 deep at that point to be able to access the elevator. Despite my acute tooth pain I dumped the paperwork in the trash and left.

text.text: Security is directing things. I was sent to the emergency room because they refused me entrance to the dental clinic. When I was sent back despite having been given a referral for the dental clinic I was told I had to go get on the information line which was 20 deep at that point to be able to access the elevator. Despite my acute tooth pain I dumped the paperwork in the trash and left.

originalText.text: Overall my experience visiting the ER wasn’t great here. One thing I noticed is that all the nurses and doctors were in a bad mood and spoke to me with a very sarcastic and degrading tone. I’ve lived in NYC my whole life and never have I felt this way about a hospital or ER room. It’s very sad that the nurses/doctors I experienced here were not empathetic and I didn’t feel cared for. They barely checked on me and everything felt so rushed and unsympathetic.
